      I know working alone has some clear advantages, but I was wondering, do you get a unique sort of satisfaction when you play with other people?

     yes

      What's that experience like for you?

     totally amazing

     
Thanks, your work ethic and pragmatism changed my life

5.10.21  3:17 pm   How do I get better at identifying chords by ear (I, IV, V, etc.)

      one small thing i could suggest is to stop using roman numerals, because they're just numbers anyway, and those all look too much the same when they keep combining the same 2 letters together. But if that's what you're used to, then that's ok. i'm just guessing that our arabic numberals (1,2,3,4 etc) might be more familiar to you (they certainly are for me). in any case, i would say you should just start going through all the songs you know and working out the chords for them, in any way you can (besides looking them up on the internet, only because that will probably get you the wrong chords), and then over time you will get really really good at it, and start to notice some patterns, then you will see all those patterns break, then if you can keep your head together you will probably start to notice patterns in how the patterns break, then of course you will see those patterns break as well, and then, somewhere around here, it's your turn

5.9.21  8:44 pm   do you think the louder you get a mix, the tighter the volume levels have to be for its elements? sometimes i want to just put a "maximizer" on my master and realize as soon as i start pumping everything, the unbalances become more noticeable, the loud start feeling louder in comparison to the mix etc. im not sure if its the maximizer, just the volume perception, or what.

      i am guessing it's not working properly. if it's doing what it's supposed to, it should even out the volume. it might be just making everything louder, because the settings might not be right for your mix and you might just be hearing the 'make up gain' by default, which would just make it louder and not do anything. (this is what happened to me in the early stages). what i would suggest is to make sure there is no make up gain, then make sure the ratio is not 1:1 (make sure the first number is higher), then raise the threshold all the way up. Now it should be doing exactly nothing. then press the bypass button on and off to compare, and it should sound exactly the same. Also check to see if there is a 'reduction' monitor so you can see when it's actually doing something. So now it should be doing nothing. Now, with the bypass off (so the compressor is ON), start gradually lowering the threshold until you start to see the 'reduction' meter gradually start to light up when it hits those loud parts, and it should be tapering them down. then once you've compressed it down a little then you can raise the make up gain

5.9.21  6:56 pm   the citi building now says altice

      that's true

5.9.21  6:07 pm   there are so many problems going on in the world: the environment, poverty, governmental issues.

     (i hope you don't forget about the good things in the world also)

     i believe that i would have the ability to dedicate myself to one of these and do my part in some way by studying applied science, economics, or politics, but at this point in my life i find myself much more focused on artistic pursuits in music and mathematics. i know artists are important to society, but i can't help but often think that my work would be better spent trying to solve those more dumpster-fire-like issues i mentioned. i know you are currently and have been for a while very fully focused on your artistic pursuits, and i admire that a lot and would enjoy being in such a position as well. but part of me feels like it's unfair for me to just dance on the sidelines while everyone else is in the middle of all the real problems. has this ever been a concern for you?

     you have a lot of mindfulness about this, which is cool, although don't let it distract you from doing the great work that you can do. Another way to think of it, here are some examples of other problems which many people in the world may face: sadness, misery, hopelessness, confusion, etc... Many of those problems might find their strongest remedy in art and music. and many people have no idea how to go about doing that. So your role as an artist/musician might be even more valuable than you realize

     as much as possible

      Thanks!

5.9.21  5:35 am   I think people keep asking "when's the album coming" because they expect you to make a fully commercial album, released by big record label, imprinted on cd/vinyl. Maybe that would be a good idea 10-15 years ago, but considering the changing circumstances in the industry, self-publishing becomes more profitable, thus more preferable option. What do you think?

      i agree. i don't even recall ever meeting a person who is capable of playing a physical CD or vinyl record

5.9.21  3:58 am   how do you prime factor numbers so well? you're great at doing it

      you have to check to see if each smaller prime number goes into it. to do that, you can modify the big number by small multiples of the small number, until you get it to something you recognize. most of the trick is to get the big number to even out to a multiple of 10, then you can drop the zeros and it still maintains its same status of whether or not it is divisible by the smaller prime number you're checking into it
